messages.content: makes sense to start looking there

Yeah so for some added context, the issue is with estimating the behaviour of the curve pool after the liquidity in the pool has changed.

When removing liquidity, the contracts first remove the liquidity from the curve pool and have some resulting vQuote & vBase. (https://github.com/increment-finance/increment-protocol-release/blob/36d6052c9c9996b3e4f148dc05ee7a654e2fbe4d/contracts/Perpetual.sol#L362-L364)

We then have to swap all the vBase to vQuote in the pool so that we can settle the account. (https://github.com/increment-finance/increment-protocol-release/blob/36d6052c9c9996b3e4f148dc05ee7a654e2fbe4d/contracts/Perpetual.sol#L377-L378)

The issue is that since the liquidity and state of the curve pool is different before the execution of the swap, we can't just estimate the proposed amount as normal. We need to use this removeLiquiditySwap function (https://github.com/increment-finance/increment-protocol-release/blob/36d6052c9c9996b3e4f148dc05ee7a654e2fbe4d/contracts/ClearingHouseViewer.sol#L621-L632) but for some reason it still does not get the amount correct, which results in a very small position and either this https://github.com/increment-finance/increment-protocol-release/blob/36d6052c9c9996b3e4f148dc05ee7a654e2fbe4d/contracts/Perpetual.sol#L916 or the minPositiveOpenNotional error

Also, `-34.999999999999999958` is probably the result of the Foundry fuzzer "reducing" the failure-inducing inputs, i.e., getting as close to not failing as possible while still failing, which is pretty standard practice for fuzzers. In other words, it can be off by more than that, and the failing `openNotional` value we see depends on the `minPositiveOpenNotional`. Which means it can't be solved by just setting `minPositiveOpenNotional = 34.99 ether`, cuz then the fuzzer will just reduce the failing inputs until it gets to `-34.989999999999999982`
I don't believe this is the same issue, I think this issue would be thrown if the reductionRatio is slightly too high

However I'm not sure if it's always off by one, or if that's dependent on the price and/or our positions.

@0xluie @omurovec I think I just made some kind of breakthrough on the AttemptReversePosition error. There seems to be an issue with the return value from `viewer.getLpProposedAmount` when given a `reductionRatio < 0.5`. I noticed that for reduction ratios from 0.5 to 1.0, the resulting `proposedAmount` scales roughly linearly, with `getLpProposedAmount(reductionRatio=0.5) ~= getLpProposedAmount(reductionRatio=1.0) / 2` and `getLpProposedAmount(reductionRatio=0.75)` falling right in the middle of those. But below 0.5, `getLpProposedAmount(reductionRatio<0.5) ~= getLpProposedAmount(reductionRatio=0.5)`, as if there's a lower limit on the value. Assuming that `proposedAmount` should continue to scale linearly below that threshold, I hardcoded a `.div(2)` appended to the `getRemoveLiquidityProposedAmount` call in the front-end and tried removing 25%, which was failing before. With half the original `proposedAmount`, removing 25% of my liquidity worked like a charm.
Obviously the `.div(2)` is not a real solution, but it seems to support my linear scaling theory

Also, on mainnet currently the proposedAmount doesn't seem to get stuck at that lower bound of `getLpProposedAmount(reductionRatio=0.5)`. If I want to withdraw 1% of my liquidity, `getLpProposedAmount(reductionRatio=0.01)` comes out to 1% of `getLpProposedAmount(reductionRatio=1.0)`. So I'm not sure why I'm hitting that lower limit on the fork from Sunday.

Got a two questions, would be interested in your thoughts @webthethird :
First some background context. When INCR is migrated from eth main to zksync, it will unfortunately lose its voting functionality (the other option is creating a custom bridge but it will come at a high development cost). Thus, we are thinking of creating a wrapper for INCR on zksync so that anyone that wraps INCR can vote. 

1. Would it be possible to integrate this with the safety module somehow, meaning that anyone who stakes INCR-only in the safety module, will receive stkINCR and we give stkINCR voting power in the new zksync governor?
2. If 1) is doable, then to avoid conflict of interest during a potential auction, would it be possible to disallow staked INCR to be auctioned off? Ie. only the staked INCRETH-LP tokens can be auctioned

Yeah I think this should be doable. I think it'd be as simple as the following:
1. Make the `slash` function `virtual` in StakedToken.sol, so we can override it, and maybe do the same for `returnFunds` and `settleSlashing`
2. Create a StakedVotingToken.sol contract, which inherits StakedToken and ERC20Votes, and which overrides `slash` so that calling it always reverts.
Awesome, thanks for that. Then we shall proceed in this direction, how does that sound to you @omurovec

we could just make a separate "vINCR" staking which allows for voting

This is a very interesting EIP. I was wondering if it might be a good alternative to a smart contract account module for our limit order implementation, but I don't think so for two reasons:
- Who knows if zkSync will even adopt it, considering they already have native AA?
- If the user gave authorization to our limit order book to act as an "invoker" when placing the order, then any subsequent tx by the user would invalidate their authorization, because:
> `AUTH` requires the `nonce` in the message be equal to the signer’s current nonce. This way, a single tx from the EOA will cause the nonce to increase, invalidating all outstanding authorizations.

So if wallets insecurely integrate 3074 *and* users do not verify the invoker they're interacting with, it is possible to delegate to a malicious invoker.
